newsitem.title: POLAND: 2,000 Polish workers march to demand govt action.
newsitem.headline: 2,000 Polish workers march to demand govt action.

text.p: About 2,000 Solidarity trade union members marched in Warsaw on Wednesday to demand more backing from Poland's leftist government for workers' jobs.

The protesters, chanting "Down with Commies (communists)" and "We want work", hurled firecrackers and paint jars at the government headquarters, smashing windows and smudging the refurbished building with red, eyewitness said.
Police looked on but did not intervene.
Among the protesters were workers from the energy sector, the bankrupt Gdansk shipyard, the Ursus tractor factory, coal miners and employees of the Swidnik aircraft plant.
The shipyard workers want the government to extend credit guarantees so that the bankrupt enterprise can finance an order for the construction of five ships from a German shipowner.

The crucial loan, of between $120 and $150 million, would keep part of the yard's 5,000-strong workforce busy building the vessels while the government and management find an investor to save the business. @
The shipyard has operated under bankruptcy regulations since August with debts of 415 million zlotys ($148 million).
The left-wing government of the Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) and the Polish Peasant Party (PSL) has said it would guarantee the loan if the yard found a bank to give the credit.
Workers of the Swidnik aircraft factory want the government to buy at least 10 of its "Sokol" helicopters.

Energy sector workers demand the abolition of energy price differences depending on the region of the country and also protest against third-party access to the energy industry, now monopolised by the state-owned PSE energy distribution firm.
The protesters handed petitions to government and parliament representatives.
